thread.title: Stocks’ reprieve in doubt after ‘mortal blow’ from Chinese data
thread.title_full: Stocks’ reprieve in doubt after ‘mortal blow’ from Chinese data - MarketWatch

author: Barbara Kollmeyer
title: Stocks’ reprieve in doubt after ‘mortal blow’ from Chinese data
text:
U.S. stock futures resumed a downward drop on Friday after a brief reprieve, folllowing downbeat data from China that may complicate efforts to come back from the worst losses of the year so far.
“As the bulls lay bleeding out at the bottom of yesterday’s session, overnight, China has delivered the mortal blow,” said Jonathan Sudaria, night dealer at London Capital Group, in a note.
An early gauge of China’s factory activity fell to a six-and-a-half-year low in August . The data come over a week after Beijing’s surprise move to devalue China’s currency.
Stock futures zigzagged, dropping sharply in Asian trading hours, recovering some in Europe, but then heading south again as New York began waking up. Futures for the S&P 500 index ESU5, -0.13% fell 3.8 points to 2,021.75, while those for the Dow industrials YMU5, -0.31% slid 72 points, or 0.4%, to 16,850. Futures for the Nasdaq-100 NQU5, -0.36% fell 18.25 points, or 0.4%, to 4,348.50.
Concerns about a slowdown in global growth, largely centered on China, drove sharp losses for Wall Street on Thursday. The main indexes turned negative for the year, with the S&P 500 index SPX, -2.11% closing down 2.1% to 2,035.73. That brought it below the 200-day moving average, a key technical level.
Read: U.S. stocks suffer worst loss of 2015 as markets end in a rout
The Nasdaq Composite COMP, -2.82% bore the brunt of the selling as investors unloaded technology stocks, which have seen some of the best performances recently. The index closed down 2.8% to 4,877.49, its sharpest one-day fall since April 10, 2014.
The S&P 500 is on course for a 2.7% loss for the week, while the Nasdaq had logged a 3.3% weekly loss up to Friday.
Read: Meet the market timer who said it would get ugly
Pressure on China, pressure on Fed: The weaker Chinese data will pressure the Federal Reserve into delaying an interest-rate increase that had been expected in September, some analysts say. But others say any delay would worry investors, as it would signal the Fed is concerned about global deflationary pressures.
“With the global growth outlook worsening and the dollar rising, a September hike could exacerbate declining risk appetite. Furthermore, recent developments may have modestly reduced the likelihood that U.S. core inflation will rise toward 2% in the medium term,” said economists at Credit Suisse in a note on Friday. They expect a December hike and say chances of a September increase by the Fed are now below 50%.
Credit Suisse and others said investors should expect Beijing will respond to the weak manufacturing data with stimulus measures.
